Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 39507  
December 2005 
 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance for 
Capacity Building for Regional Cooperation in 
Central Asia 
(Financed by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction 
and Regional Cooperation Fund)

2   
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation

  MC  –  ministerial conference

  OIF  –  overall institutional framework 
  PRC Fund  –  People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sectors  –  Multisector (transport and communications, energy, industry and

Subsectors  –  Multimodal transport and sector development, energy sector

NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice President   J. B. Eichenberger, Operations Group 2 
Director General  H. S. Rao, East and Central Asia Department (ECRD) 
Director  A. H. Ruthenberg, Operations Coordination Division, ECRD 
 
Team leader  Q. Zhang, Senior Regional Cooperation Programs Specialist, ECRD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  initiated  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation (CAREC) Program in 1997. The countries participating in the Program currently 
consist of Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, People’s Republic of China, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, 
Mongolia,  Tajikistan,  and  Uzbekistan.  ADB  has  a  strong  relationship  with  each  of  these 
countries and serves as program Secretariat for CAREC.1  
 
2.  In  October  2004,  the  Senior  Officials’  Meeting  (SOM)  of  CAREC  highlighted  in  its 
progress report to the third Ministerial Conference (MC) the importance of capacity-building to 
enhance country ownership of the CAREC Program, and welcomed ADB’s support in this area. 
Ministers at the fourth MC in November 2005 further indicated that capacity-building should 
focus on strengthening the national focal points (NFPs), conducting training workshops and 
study tours concerning international best practices for regional cooperation, and information 
exchange and research networks.2 
 
3.  ADB recognized in its CAREC Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program the need to 
increase technical assistance (TA) for capacity-building in CAREC participating countries.3 This 
position goes along with the thrust of the enhanced poverty reduction strategy (PRS), which 
elevated capacity development to one of the five priority themes of the PRS.4 
 
4.  On 25 March 2005, the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund (PRC Fund) was established, with a view, among others, to strengthening the 
capacity  of  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  to  reduce  poverty  through  regional 
cooperation.5 This TA was proposed by ADB's Regional Cooperation Committee6 for financing 
by the PRC Fund, which has endorsed the proposal and earmarked for it the amount of 
$400,000. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The CAREC Program operates through its overall institutional framework (OIF), which 
consists  of  (i)  an  annual  MC  that  provides  overall  guidance  and  directions,  (ii)  SOM  that 
coordinates  cross-sectoral  issues  and  prepares  for  the  MC,  (iii)  sectoral  coordinating 
committees at the operational level that coordinate sectorwide issues and implementation, and 
(iv) a NFP in each participating country to ensure effective coordination among government 
agencies and other concerned parties. The capacity of government officials involved in the OIF 
was found critical to the success of regional initiatives under the CAREC Program.8 
 
                                                 
1  Apart from ADB, five other multilateral institutions also provide assistance to regional cooperation in Central Asia 
with CAREC as a platform: (i) European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, (ii) International Monetary 
Fund, (iii) Islamic Development Bank, (iv) United Nations Development Programme, and (v) World Bank.  
2  Fourth Ministerial Conference on CAREC. 2005. Joint Ministerial Statement. Bishkek (para. 12). 
3  ADB. 2004. Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Member Countries Regional Cooperation Strategy and 
Program (2005–2007). Manila (IN.158-04, para. 92). 
4  ADB. 2004. Review of the Asian Development Bank’s Poverty Reduction Strategy. Manila (R95-04, paras. 79–80, 
and 118). 
5  ADB. 2005. People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund. Manila (R78-05).  
6  Acting as the PRC Fund Committee in accordance with Appendix 1, R78-05 (footnote 5). 
7  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 19 July 2005.

2   
6.  Currently, there is an ongoing TA, i.e. TA 6158,9 focusing on capacity-building under the 
CAREC  Program.  Major  reasons  that  underlay  TA  6158  are  as  follows:  (i)  preparation  of 
intercountry projects and programs is inherently more complex and requires a multicountry 
perspective; (ii) progress and success in regional cooperation hinge on the capacity of officials 
of the participating countries to identify and address cross-country policy issues and integrate 
these  into  the  domestic  development  strategy;  (iii)  high-level  forum  and  networking  are 
important in fostering dialogue and sustaining mutual trust on regional cooperation; and (iv) in 
view of the vital role of the NFPs in coordinating and championing the regional cooperation 
initiatives within the administrations, they need to be given targeted and individually tailored 
training. The purpose of TA 6158 was to strengthen the capacity for regional cooperation so that 
participating countries can assume greater roles and responsibilities in planning, implementing, 
and coordinating the CAREC Program. To this end, TA 6158 is set to finance the development 
of a comprehensive capacity-building assessment plan and to support a series of activities 
under the following core components: (i) strengthening the NFPs, (ii) training national officials 
involved in regional cooperation, and (iii) enhancing information exchange and understanding of 
the benefits of regional cooperation. 
  
7.  The needs assessment undertaken under TA 6158 was presented to the SOM in April 
2005.  Major  findings  based  on  consultations  with  CAREC  countries  included  (i)  common 
priorities identified for capacity-building;10 (ii) special interests or priorities of individual countries, 
and (iii) possible themes/actions of capacity-building. As noted in the needs assessment note, 
the wish list of capacity-building themes and actions could not be fully accommodated by TA 
6158 with its limited resources of $950,000. Using a “building-block” approach, some of the 
capacity-building components will clearly have to be financed by additional resources.  
 
8.  The PRC Fund provides an opportunity to scale up and complement TA 6158 and to 
contribute  to  full  achievement  of  its  purpose  for  CAREC  capacity-building.  In  fact, 
complementary but distinct use of the PRC Fund from ADB’s core financing sources has also 
been one of the requirements of the Fund. Apart from this, other basic principles as set forth in 
the Board paper on the PRC Fund will be followed in the design and implementation of the TA: 
(i) alignment of the programs with the Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program and its 
update; (ii) use of DMC expertise to the extent possible; and (iii) the requirement that the PRC 
Fund be used in the most cost-effective way possible.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  In view of the complementary nature of this project, the impact of the TA will continue to 
be  strengthening  the  capacity  of  the  participating  countries  to  assume  greater  roles  and 
responsibilities in planning, implementing, and coordinating the CAREC Program. Because of 
the  importance  and  primary  role  of  NFPs  and  other  senior  officials  in  coordinating  and 
implementing  regional  cooperation  initiatives  at  the  country  level,  and  taking  into  account 
specific requirements of the PRC Fund (para. 8), the outcome of the TA will focus on enhancing 
the capabilities and functions of NFPs. The outcome will be achieved by the following major 
outputs: (i) further development of the skills in policy planning and strategic management for 
regional cooperation of NFPs and other senior officials responsible for the CAREC Program, (ii) 
                                                 
9  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Regional Cooperation in Central Asia. Manila (R9-04). 
10 Including (i) strengthening interest in and commitment to cooperation, (ii) strengthening national focal points 
(NFPs), (iii) mechanism for sharing regional cooperation experience and international best practices, and (iv) 
mechanisms for intersector coordination. (CAREC. 2005. Background Note on Capacity Building for Regional 
Cooperation in Central Asia. Manila.)

3
experience learned from other regional cooperation programs, (iii) process to be instituted to 
coordinate regional initiatives at the country level, and (iv) research networks developed in 
support of the decision-making process and subsequent implementation of regional cooperation 
initiatives.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The approach of the TA is to complement TA 6158, focusing on strengthening NFPs, 
which have a central place in coordinating and taking forward the CAREC Program at the 
country level. To ensure high impact, relevance, and coherence of the programs, the TA will 
include the following features: (i) the capacity-building events and topics will be determined 
based on a survey of NFPs in the participating countries; (ii) as an integral part of the TA, an 
appropriate  measurement  mechanism  will  be  developed  by  a  training  specialist  to  assess 
competencies achieved and guide further improvement of the succeeding programs; (iii) the 
resource  speakers  will  be  selected  from  leading  scholars  in  the  relevant  areas,  with  the 
assistance of the regional cooperation specialists/coordinators based in ADB’s field offices; (iv) 
presentations, background notes, and other reading materials for each capacity development 
event  will  be  compiled  in  CD-ROM  for  future  reference  by  the  participants  and  wide 
dissemination to their colleagues and other stakeholders, as appropriate, in the participating 
countries; and (v) resource speakers are expected to also contribute to establishing research 
and  knowledge  dissemination  networks  in  support  of  the  decision-making  process  and 
subsequent implementation of regional cooperation. Key activities that will be funded by the TA 
will include the following.  
 
11.  High-Level Learning Program. Training and workshops will be organized on policy 
planning and strategic management for regional cooperation. Training modules may comprise  
principles,  methodologies,  and  process  of  programming  for  regional  cooperation;  national 
versus regional project identification; judging the relative benefits of and mobilizing resources for 
regional cooperation; strategic management and team building for regional cooperation; case 
studies  of  regional  cooperation  in  South  Asia,  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS),  and/or 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), etc. Final selection of the topics will be based 
on a survey or other forms of consultation with NFPs of the participating countries. The learning 
program will be high-impact events, targeting NFPs and other senior officials in charge of policy 
planning and strategic management for the CAREC Program in the participating countries. 
 
12.  Cross-Learning and Networking. Cross-learning and networking programs will provide 
NFPs and concerned senior officials with an opportunity to discuss, network, and interact with 
their peers working on other regional cooperation programs. These events are expected to 
reinforce confidence in the benefits of and commitment to regional cooperation, provide insights 
and firsthand information on experiences and lessons learned from other regional initiatives, 
inspire new ideas and approaches, and establish useful contacts for continuing exchange of 
information and knowledge sharing in the future. 
 
13.  Instituting  a  Process  to  Coordinate  Regional  Initiatives  at  the  Country  Level. 
Coordinating regional initiatives at the country level is the core function of the NFP. The fact is 
coordination among different administrations may turn out to be inefficient and ineffective. Thus, 
a suitable coordinating process must be instituted to minimize sporadic courses of action. 
Brainstorming and experience sharing on the process will be undertaken at the training and 
cross-learning  events.  Research  and  proposals  for  more  systematic  solutions  will  also  be 
commissioned by engaging appropriate consulting services.

4   
14.  Developing Research and Knowledge Dissemination Networks in Support of the 
Decision-Making  Process  and  Subsequent  Implementation  of  Regional  Cooperation 
Initiatives. The capacity of NFPs to coordinate and make decisions on regional cooperation 
also depends on whether they can have prompt access to pertinent analysis, advice, and 
information. To this end, the TA will help develop a research and knowledge dissemination 
network in each participating country (including a record of first-rate outputs), with resource 
speakers and leading scholars on regional cooperation in the DMC concerned as the backbone 
and key players.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the PRC Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund and administered 
by ADB. The participating governments will provide the remaining $50,000 equivalent, equal to 
the imputed value of staff time and use of government facilities for activities under the TA. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from February 2006 to July 2007. ADB will 
be the Executing Agency for the TA. ADB’s CAREC Unit in the Operations Coordination Division 
will  be  responsible  for  overall  implementation  of  TA  activities,  and  the  CAREC  regional 
cooperation coordinators in ADB’s field offices will provide proactive assistance in determining 
details  of  the  training  topics/capacity-building  events,  selecting  domestic  consultants  and 
resource speakers, and making meeting and other necessary arrangements. There will be close 
coordination  with  NFPs  of  the  CAREC  countries,  as  well  as  with  the  ongoing  capacity 
development activities financed by TA 6158.  
 
17.  For implementation of the TA, domestic consultants will be engaged, for 4 person-
months  on  intermittent  basis,  to  (i)  develop  a  measurement  mechanism  and  conduct 
performance  assessment;  (ii)  develop  criteria,  process,  and  procedures  for  selecting 
participants in the capacity-building events and determining the topics; (iii) assist with instituting 
a process to coordinate regional initiatives at the country level; and (iv) help develop research 
and knowledge dissemination networks. In addition, up to 24 resource speakers will be required, 
to lecture or lead discussions at the capacity-building events. ADB will engage the consultants 
and resource speakers in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. An outline of the terms of 
reference for consultants and resource speakers is in Appendix 3. One desktop computer (PC) 
is budgeted under the TA for the project secretariat. The PC will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and will be left with ADB at the completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation 
Fund for Capacity Building for Regional Cooperation in Central Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Domestic consulting services totaling 4 person-months and up to 24 resource speakers 
will be required in the technical assistance (TA). Given that the TA will support a range of 
capacity development activities for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
Program, whose modules or topics will be finally determined in consultation with the national 
focal points (NFPs) of the participating countries, detailed terms of reference for specific tasks 
may be revised and supplemented at a later stage. 
 
A.  Training Specialists (domestic, 2 person-months) 
2.  Two training specialists will be engaged as independent individual consultants for a total 
of 2 person-months to undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Develop  a  measurement  mechanism,  including  performance  indicators,  to 
assess  competencies  achieved  in  the  training  and  cross-learning/networking 
activities. 
 
(ii)  Ensure  user-friendliness  and  suitability  of  the  proposed  measurement 
mechanism  for  high-level  training  and  cross-learning/networking  of  senior 
government officials in the context of the CAREC Program. 
 
(iii)  Deliver a report that presents the measurement mechanism, including (a) the 
objectives and principles of measuring performance in capacity development 
activities,  (b)  major  measurement  tools  and  indicators,  (c)  how  to  use  the 
measurement tools to achieve the intended objectives, (d) a whole set of forms 
or matrices required, (e) a detailed example that shows all steps in the process of 
assessing  training  and  cross-learning/networking  activities;  and  (f)  a  list  of 
reading materials or publications on the internet, for further study of the subject. 
 
(iv)  Deliver a report on a proposed methodology for selecting the participants and 
determining the topics in the capacity-building events, including criteria, process, 
and procedures to be taken, together with a whole set of user-friendly forms, 
questionnaires, and other relevant tools. 
 
3.  The reports will be submitted to the Asian Development Bank (ADB), Executing Agency 
of the TA, to help ensure high impact, relevance, and coherence of the programs.  
 
B.  Institution/Organization Specialists (domestic, 2 person-months) 
4.  Two independent individual consultants will be engaged for a total of 2 person-months to 
undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Deliver a report on instituting a process to coordinate regional initiatives at the 
country level, including (a) major patterns of coordination among ministries or 
between  the  central  and  provincial  governments;  (b)  major  constraints  and 
problems in coordination among administrations; (c) possible options to solve 
problems faced in the context of regional cooperation in Central Asia; (d) how to 
implement the proposed options; (e) presentation of a real case on instituting the 
process  of  coordination  among  administrations,  with  a  summary  of  major

Appendix 3      9 
experiences  and  lessons  learned;  and  (f)  a  list  of  reading  materials  or 
publications on the internet, to further study the subject.  
 
(ii)  Advise on developing a research and knowledge dissemination network in each 
participating  country  (including  a  record  of  first-rate  outputs)  to  increase 
interaction between the Government and the academia (including the resource 
speakers and other leading scholars), and support the NFP in the decision-
making  process  and  subsequent  implementation  of  regional  cooperation 
initiatives. The output will include delivering a report that identifies major issues 
and proposes different options for suitable solution.  
 
5.  The  reports  will  be  submitted  to  ADB,  and  shared  with  NFPs  and  concerned 
stakeholders.  
 
C.  Resource Speakers (up to 24 persons) 
6.  The  resource  speakers  will  be  engaged  from  leading  scholars  or  experienced 
practitioners specializing in the topics selected for the capacity-building events, such as (i) 
principles, methodologies, and process of programming for regional cooperation; (ii) national 
versus  regional  project  identification;  (iii)  judging  the  relative  benefits  of  and  mobilizing 
resources for regional cooperation; (iv) strategic management and team building for regional 
cooperation; or (v) major initiatives for regional cooperation in Central Asia, South Asia, Greater 
Mekong Subregion and/or Association of Southeast Asian Nations. 
 
7.  Major responsibilities of each resource speaker are the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare  the  training  and  reading  materials  for  the  topic  under  his/her 
responsibility. 
(ii)  Prepare a detailed schedule for the session under his/her responsibility at the 
training workshop or cross-learning/networking event. 
(iii)  Present and lead discussion at the relevant session of the training workshop or 
cross-learning/networking event. 
(iv)  Compile the presentation, background notes and other reading materials on the 
topic under his/her responsibility in a CD-ROM, and give full authorization to ADB 
as the Executing Agency of the TA to post the CD-ROM on the CAREC website 
and/or reproduce it and disseminate the copies to government officials and other 
stakeholders in the participating countries, as appropriate.   
(v)  Contribute to establishing research and knowledge dissemination networks in 
support  of  the  decision-making  process  and  subsequent  implementation  of 
regional cooperation.
